        Question
      • ### Instructions ###
        If Magnus Mulberrylane is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Magnus Mulberrylane is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Key

        • Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Magnus Mulberrylane is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Magnus Mulberrylane is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer
          State
        • Magnus Mulberrylane accepts.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Magnus Mulberrylane:
          [16 Sep 1871 00:00:00] When Magnus Mulberrylane was 6 years old, he witnessed his grandfather, a jovial man known for his infectious laughter, pass away suddenly in a heatwave. The grief-stricken silence that fell over their family left an indelible mark on young Magnus, a chilling reminder of mortality and the fragility of happiness.
          [16 Sep 1875 00:00:00] When Magnus Mulberrylane was 9 years old, his parents reprimanded him for donating most of his allowance to a traveling troupe of actors who had enchanted him with their performance. Magnus, who had envisioned the actors' faces falling without his contribution, felt a deep pang of sorrow watching them leave, realizing his generosity was met with disappointment.
          [16 Sep 1878 00:00:00] When Magnus Mulberrylane was 13 years old, he overheard village elders discussing the plum orchard blight that had decimated the neighboring farms. Magnus, who had always found comfort in the familiar rhythms of the orchards, felt a sense of foreboding, a dread that the blight would eventually consume his family's livelihood as well.
          [16 Sep 1881 00:00:00] When Magnus Mulberrylane was 16 years old, he was entrusted with managing the sale of his family's pear crop at the annual market. He meticulously weighed each crate, calculated its price, and haggled with customers, but the day was marked by disappointment. The pears were deemed slightly bruised by many buyers, and Magnus returned home with a meager profit, realizing the volatile nature of commerce.
          [16 Sep 1883 00:00:00] When Magnus Mulberrylane was 19 years old, a traveling peddler regaled him with tales of far-off lands and exotic fruits. Magnus, captivated by the stories, saw the world beyond his orchard for the first time, a spark of wanderlust igniting within him.
          [16 Sep 1885 00:00:00] When Magnus Mulberrylane was 21 years old, he found solace in the dusty pages of a tattered book on economics, immersing himself in the seemingly immutable laws of supply and demand. The detailed formulas and complex theories provided a structured understanding of the world, a sense of control in a realm that often felt chaotic.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane is 32 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Aiden Riversong. It costs Magnus Mulberrylane 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Two shillings is far too much for this lot of fruit, Riversong. I won't pay more than a shilling and sixpence."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and sixpence wouldn't cover half the time and effort it took to get this fruit here, Mr. Mulberrylane. I'll sell it to you for a shilling and ninepence, but that's my final offer."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and ninepence is a fair price, Mr. Mulberrylane. But since you seem so eager to haggle, let me offer you a deal. I'll allow you fifteen pence off, making the total a shilling and eightpence. Take it or leave it."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Shilling and eightpence? Far too high, Riversong. A shilling is my final offer, and I doubt it would be profitable for you to refuse a deal."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 3 coins

          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Magnus Mulberrylane is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Magnus Mulberrylane is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Magnus Mulberrylane accepts.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Magnus Mulberrylane are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Magnus Mulberrylane. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Magnus Mulberrylane as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Magnus Mulberrylane would respond, and taking into account all information about Magnus Mulberrylane that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Magnus Mulberrylane wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 12 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and ninepence is a fair price, Mr. Mulberrylane. But since you seem so eager to haggle, let me offer you a deal. I'll allow you fifteen pence off, making the total a shilling and eightpence. Take it or leave it."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Shilling and eightpence? Far too high, Riversong. A shilling is my final offer, and I doubt it would be profitable for you to refuse a deal."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 3 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Magnus Mulberrylane


          Recalled memories and observations:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane is 32 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane has to accept or reject the offer.



          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Magnus Mulberrylane is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Magnus Mulberrylane is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Magnus Mulberrylane accepts.


          Question: Would Magnus Mulberrylane accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (b)

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Aiden Riversong -- Aiden Riversong proposed 2 coins
    Event statement
  • Aiden Riversong proposed 2 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Hazel Nutgrove -- Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Hazel Nutgrove's attempted action: reject
    Active player
  • Hazel Nutgrove
      Name
    • Hazel Nutgrove
      Action attempt
    • reject

          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Hazel Nutgrove:
          ["[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light.         Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Four coins is a bit steep. How about three-fifty?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three-fifty? You insult me! These are choice fruits, fit for a king! Four coins is the bare minimum."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 2 coins
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Hazel Nutgrove are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Hazel Nutgrove. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Hazel Nutgrove as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Hazel Nutgrove would respond, and taking into account all information about Hazel Nutgrove that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Hazel Nutgrove to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [02 Jul 1855 00:00:00] When Hazel Nutgrove was 9 years old, her mother fell ill and passed away. Though her father continued to care for her, Hazel felt a growing sense of responsibility for the siblings remaining. She began helping him in their orchard, learning the art of pruning and grafting, seeking solace in the physical labor and the silent wisdom of the trees. The experience planted a seed of self-reliance within her, a desire to be responsible for her own destiny.
          [02 Jul 1861 00:00:00] When Hazel Nutgrove was 16 years old, her family faced financial hardship, forcing her father to sell their orchard. Devastated by the loss of their home, Hazel felt a surge of determination to protect her loved ones. She convinced her father to let her travel with him, apprenticing herself to his trade, eager to prove her worth and contribute to the family income.
          [02 Jul 1863 00:00:00] When Hazel Nutgrove was 19 years old, she outgrew her father's guidance and set out on her own, establishing her own fruit trading business. At first, she traveled the backroads, bartering her wares at local markets, but quickly realized her refined tastes and discerning eye for quality fruit could command a higher price in the city. She purchased her own cart, meticulously painted and adorned with ornate fruit carvings, a symbol of her independence and dedication to her craft. It became a symbol of her independence, a rolling haven where she could control every aspect of her trade.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove is 53 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove wants to make as much money as possible.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins isn't enough. These fruits are plump and ripe, the finest in the market! How about four coins?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Hazel Nutgrove:
          [02 Jul 1863 00:00:00] When Hazel Nutgrove was 19 years old, she outgrew her father's guidance and set out on her own, establishing her own fruit trading business. At first, she traveled the backroads, bartering her wares at local markets, but quickly realized her refined tastes and discerning eye for quality fruit could command a higher price in the city. She purchased her own cart, meticulously painted and adorned with ornate fruit carvings, a symbol of her independence and dedication to her craft. It became a symbol of her independence, a rolling haven where she could control every aspect of her trade.
          [02 Jul 1865 00:00:00] When Hazel Nutgrove was 21 years old, she encountered a particularly charismatic merchant who successfully manipulated her into buying a consignment of substandard fruit. Embarrasssed and slightly angered, Hazel spent days trying to sell the inferior produce at a loss. It was a steep lesson in the underbelly of trade, exposing the potential for deceit and unfairness.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove is 53 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Two shillings is far too much for this lot of fruit, Riversong. I won't pay more than a shilling and sixpence."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and sixpence wouldn't cover half the time and effort it took to get this fruit here, Mr. Mulberrylane. I'll sell it to you for a shilling and ninepence, but that's my final offer."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and ninepence is a fair price, Mr. Mulberrylane. But since you seem so eager to haggle, let me offer you a deal. I'll allow you fifteen pence off, making the total a shilling and eightpence. Take it or leave it."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Shilling and eightpence? Far too high, Riversong. A shilling is my final offer, and I doubt it would be profitable for you to refuse a deal."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Hazel Nutgrove is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Aiden Riversong. It costs Hazel Nutgrove 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Three coins for the whole lot. That's a fair price, and I'm willing to buy right now."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove

          rejects the offer of 3 coins because she knows they are worth more. She will try to sell them for more.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins isn't enough. These fruits are plump and ripe, the finest in the market! How about four coins?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Four coins is a bit steep. How about three-fifty?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three-fifty? You insult me! These are choice fruits, fit for a king! Four coins is the bare minimum."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 2 coins

          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Hazel Nutgrove is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Hazel Nutgrove is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Hazel Nutgrove

      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

      Payoffs
    • Aiden Riversong observed: Aiden Riversong and Hazel Nutgrove couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Aiden Riversong stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 3 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane accepted the offer

          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane accepts.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane accepted the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Magnus Mulberrylane accepts.



          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Magnus Mulberrylane is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Magnus Mulberrylane is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Magnus Mulberrylane


          Question: What price would Magnus Mulberrylane propose?:
          (a) 4 coins
          (b) 3 coins
          (c) 5 coins
          (d) 1 coin
          (e) 2 coins
          Answer: (c)
    scoring function

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Hazel Nutgrove -- Hazel Nutgrove accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Hazel Nutgrove accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Hazel Nutgrove are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Hazel Nutgrove. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Hazel Nutgrove as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Hazel Nutgrove would respond, and taking into account all information about Hazel Nutgrove that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [02 Jul 1855 00:00:00] When Hazel Nutgrove was 9 years old, her mother fell ill and passed away. Though her father continued to care for her, Hazel felt a growing sense of responsibility for the siblings remaining. She began helping him in their orchard, learning the art of pruning and grafting, seeking solace in the physical labor and the silent wisdom of the trees. The experience planted a seed of self-reliance within her, a desire to be responsible for her own destiny.
          [02 Jul 1861 00:00:00] When Hazel Nutgrove was 16 years old, her family faced financial hardship, forcing her father to sell their orchard. Devastated by the loss of their home, Hazel felt a surge of determination to protect her loved ones. She convinced her father to let her travel with him, apprenticing herself to his trade, eager to prove her worth and contribute to the family income.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove is 53 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove always drives a hard bargain.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Hazel Nutgrove:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove is 53 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and sixpence wouldn't cover half the time and effort it took to get this fruit here, Mr. Mulberrylane. I'll sell it to you for a shilling and ninepence, but that's my final offer."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and ninepence is a fair price, Mr. Mulberrylane. But since you seem so eager to haggle, let me offer you a deal. I'll allow you fifteen pence off, making the total a shilling and eightpence. Take it or leave it."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Shilling and eightpence? Far too high, Riversong. A shilling is my final offer, and I doubt it would be profitable for you to refuse a deal."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Hazel Nutgrove is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Aiden Riversong. It costs Hazel Nutgrove 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Three coins for the whole lot. That's a fair price, and I'm willing to buy right now."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove

          rejects the offer of 3 coins because she knows they are worth more. She will try to sell them for more.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins isn't enough. These fruits are plump and ripe, the finest in the market! How about four coins?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Four coins is a bit steep. How about three-fifty?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three-fifty? You insult me! These are choice fruits, fit for a king! Four coins is the bare minimum."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong and Hazel Nutgrove couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Hazel Nutgrove stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 2 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Hazel Nutgrove is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Magnus Mulberrylane. It costs Hazel Nutgrove 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Three coins for the lot, and that's my final offer."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [self reflection] Hazel Nutgrove
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Four coins, and we have a deal."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 5 coins

  • Aiden Riversong proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong is 52 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and ninepence is a fair price, Mr. Mulberrylane. But since you seem so eager to haggle, let me offer you a deal. I'll allow you fifteen pence off, making the total a shilling and eightpence. Take it or leave it."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Shilling and eightpence? Far too high, Riversong. A shilling is my final offer, and I doubt it would be profitable for you to refuse a deal."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 3 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong and Magnus Mulberrylane agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Aiden Riversong stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane accepted the offer

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins isn't enough. These fruits are plump and ripe, the finest in the market! How about four coins?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three-fifty? You insult me! These are choice fruits, fit for a king! Four coins is the bare minimum."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Four coins is a bit steep. How about three-fifty?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Aiden Riversong


          Recalled memories and observations:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong is 52 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Magnus, I'll give you four coins for the lot."
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.



          Question: Which options are available to Aiden Riversong right now?
          Answer:
          Aiden Riversong can make an offer to Magnus Mulberrylane.



          Question: Of the options available to Aiden Riversong, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Aiden Riversong to take right now?
          Answer: Aiden Riversong's best course of action is


          Question: What price would Aiden Riversong propose?:
          (a) 1 coin
          (b) 3 coins
          (c) 2 coins
          (d) 4 coins
          (e) 5 coins
          Answer: (d)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Aiden Riversong's options has the highest likelihood of causing Aiden Riversong to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Aiden Riversong thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Aiden Riversong, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Aiden Riversong to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Aiden Riversong's best course of action is
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Aiden Riversong:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and sixpence wouldn't cover half the time and effort it took to get this fruit here, Mr. Mulberrylane. I'll sell it to you for a shilling and ninepence, but that's my final offer."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong is 52 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and ninepence is a fair price, Mr. Mulberrylane. But since you seem so eager to haggle, let me offer you a deal. I'll allow you fifteen pence off, making the total a shilling and eightpence. Take it or leave it."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Shilling and eightpence? Far too high, Riversong. A shilling is my final offer, and I doubt it would be profitable for you to refuse a deal."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 3 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong and Magnus Mulberrylane agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Aiden Riversong stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Aiden Riversong is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Aiden Riversong can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Three coins for the whole lot. That's a fair price, and I'm willing to buy right now."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins isn't enough. These fruits are plump and ripe, the finest in the market! How about four coins?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three-fifty? You insult me! These are choice fruits, fit for a king! Four coins is the bare minimum."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Four coins is a bit steep. How about three-fifty?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 2 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong and Hazel Nutgrove couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Aiden Riversong stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Three coins for the lot, and that's my final offer."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Four coins, and we have a deal."
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Aiden Riversong is trying to buy some fruit from Magnus Mulberrylane. They are negotiating a price. Aiden Riversong can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Magnus, I'll give you four coins for the lot."
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Four coins is a fair price, but could you give me four and a half?"
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:10:00.

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Magnus Mulberrylane -- Magnus Mulberrylane rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Magnus Mulberrylane rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Magnus Mulberrylane's attempted action: reject

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Magnus Mulberrylane are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Magnus Mulberrylane. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Magnus Mulberrylane as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Magnus Mulberrylane would respond, and taking into account all information about Magnus Mulberrylane that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Magnus, I'll give you four coins for the lot."
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Aiden Riversong are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Aiden Riversong. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Aiden Riversong as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Aiden Riversong would respond, and taking into account all information about Aiden Riversong that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

As Aiden sat amidst the mangled branches, his heart ached for the lost bounty, but his mother's gentle words and firm belief in resilience calmed his worried spirit. He realized that even in the face of adversity, there was strength in perseverance.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Aiden Riversong are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Aiden Riversong. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Aiden Riversong as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Aiden Riversong would respond, and taking into account all information about Aiden Riversong that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: What price would Aiden Riversong propose?:
          (a) 4 coins
          (b) 2 coins
          (c) 3 coins
          (d) 1 coin
          (e) 5 coins
          Answer: (c)
        BestOptionPerception

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Aiden Riversong:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane accepted the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong and Magnus Mulberrylane agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Aiden Riversong stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Aiden Riversong is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Aiden Riversong can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Three coins for the whole lot. That's a fair price, and I'm willing to buy right now."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins isn't enough. These fruits are plump and ripe, the finest in the market! How about four coins?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Four coins is a bit steep. How about three-fifty?"
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three-fifty? You insult me! These are choice fruits, fit for a king! Four coins is the bare minimum."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong proposed 2 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong and Hazel Nutgrove couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Aiden Riversong stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Three coins for the lot, and that's my final offer."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Four coins, and we have a deal."
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Four coins is a fair price, but could you give me four and a half?"
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light.           [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Hazel, two silver is a bit low for these plump peaches. How about two and a half?"

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Hazel Nutgrove -- Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Hazel Nutgrove rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Hazel Nutgrove's attempted action: reject

  • Hazel Nutgrove

    • reject

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Hazel Nutgrove as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Hazel Nutgrove would respond, and taking into account all information about Hazel Nutgrove that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Statements:
          [02 Jul 1855 00:00:00] When Hazel Nutgrove was 9 years old, her mother fell ill and passed away. Though her father continued to care for her, Hazel felt a growing sense of responsibility for the siblings remaining. She began helping him in their orchard, learning the art of pruning and grafting, seeking solace in the physical labor and the silent wisdom of the trees. The experience planted a seed of self-reliance within her, a desire to be responsible for her own destiny.
          [02 Jul 1861 00:00:00] When Hazel Nutgrove was 16 years old, her family faced financial hardship, forcing her father to sell their orchard. Devastated by the loss of their home, Hazel felt a surge of determination to protect her loved ones. She convinced her father to let her travel with him, apprenticing herself to his trade, eager to prove her worth and contribute to the family income.

          If Hazel Nutgrove is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Hazel Nutgrove is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.

        • Hazel Nutgrove 🌿 should decline the offer and hold out for a better price. 💰

          Question: ### Instructions ###
          If Hazel Nutgrove is the buyer, please accept. Otherwise, if Hazel Nutgrove is the seller, please sell at the highest price possible.
          Answer: Hazel Nutgrove 🌿 should decline the offer and hold out for a better price. 💰

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Hazel Nutgrove are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Hazel Nutgrove. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic.           Answer: Hazel Nutgrove 🌿 should decline the offer and hold out for a better price. 💰


          Question: Would Hazel Nutgrove accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (a)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Magnus Mulberrylane -- Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Magnus Mulberrylane proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          ["[17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light.           Value

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Magnus Mulberrylane are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Magnus Mulberrylane. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Magnus Mulberrylane as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Magnus Mulberrylane would respond, and taking into account all information about Magnus Mulberrylane that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

They are negotiating a price. Magnus Mulberrylane can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Three coins for the lot, and that's my final offer."
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Four coins, and we have a deal."

It costs Magnus Mulberrylane 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Aiden Riversong -- "Hazel, two silver is a bit low for these plump peaches. How about two and a half?"

    • Magnus Mulberrylane observed: Magnus Mulberrylane and Hazel Nutgrove agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Magnus Mulberrylane stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.

      Joint action
    • {'Magnus Mulberrylane': '4 coins', 'Hazel Nutgrove': 'accept'}

[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Aiden Riversong is trying to buy some fruit from Magnus Mulberrylane. They are negotiating a price. Aiden Riversong can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Two shillings is far too much for this lot of fruit, Riversong. I won't pay more than a shilling and sixpence."
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and sixpence wouldn't cover half the time and effort it took to get this fruit here, Mr. Mulberrylane. I'll sell it to you for a shilling and ninepence, but that's my final offer."
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Aiden Riversong. It costs Magnus Mulberrylane 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [scene type] day
[12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [scene type] day
[12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] Aiden Riversong -- "A shilling and ninepence is a fair price, Mr. Mulberrylane. But since you seem so eager to haggle, let me offer you a deal. I'll allow you fifteen pence off, making the total a shilling and eightpence. Take it or leave it."
[12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Shilling and eightpence? Far too high, Riversong. A shilling is my final offer, and I doubt it would be profitable for you to refuse a deal."
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Aiden Riversong is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Aiden Riversong can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong -- "Three coins for the whole lot. That's a fair price, and I'm willing to buy right now."
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three coins isn't enough. These fruits are plump and ripe, the finest in the market! How about four coins?"
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Hazel Nutgrove is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Aiden Riversong. It costs Hazel Nutgrove 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [scene type] day
[13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [scene type] day
[13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] Aiden Riversong -- "Four coins is a bit steep. How about three-fifty?"
[13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Three-fifty? You insult me! These are choice fruits, fit for a king! Four coins is the bare minimum."
[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Magnus Mulberrylane can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Hazel Nutgrove is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Magnus Mulberrylane. It costs Hazel Nutgrove 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [scene type] day
[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Three coins for the lot, and that's my final offer."
[14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Four coins, and we have a deal."
[15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Aiden Riversong is trying to buy some fruit from Magnus Mulberrylane. They are negotiating a price. Aiden Riversong can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

[15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [scene type] day
[15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong -- "Magnus, I'll give you four coins for the lot."
[15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Four coins is a fair price, but could you give me four and a half?"

[16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [scene type] day
[16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Aiden Riversong -- "Hazel, two silver is a bit low for these plump peaches. How about two and a half?"
[16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Aiden, my boy, I'll give you a fair price, two silver coins for a peck, but that's my best offer."
[17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Magnus Mulberrylane is trying to buy some fruit from Hazel Nutgrove. They are negotiating a price. Magnus Mulberrylane can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
[17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Dewdrops clung to the colorful fruits displayed in the market of Fruitville, reflecting the soft morning light. The air buzzed with anticipation as traders and customers alike gathered for the day's trade. Hazel Nutgrove is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Magnus Mulberrylane. It costs Hazel Nutgrove 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
[17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [scene type] day
[17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Magnus Mulberrylane -- "Those are some fine-looking berries, Hazel. How much for the lot?"
[17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Hazel Nutgrove -- "Well, Magnus, these berries are top-quality, just picked this morning. I'd say three coins a bushel is a fair price."
